Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Experimental Investigation of Failure Modes and Mechanics of Earthquakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Small amplitude slow slip events were discovered at both the updip and downdip limits of the subduction zones where tsunami-generating mega earthquakes occur. Understanding the physics of these events may provide constraints on stress transfer and loading that potentially lead to great earthquakes. The proposed study will focus on investigating the possible mechanisms for generating very low frequency earthquakes (VLFEs) detected in the Nankai accretionary prism. The mechanisms that trigger these un-earthquake like seismic signals are controversial. The project involves an experimental investigation on the failure mechanisms related to pore pressure excess, which is widely cited for triggering slip that induces VLFEs. Using an integrated approach consists of deformation and frictional experiments, microstructural analyses, and numerical modeling on slip and failure associated with the observed seismic events, the project's goal is to gain better understanding of the fundamental mechanics of shallow VLFEs.
The multidisciplinary and hands-on nature of experimental studies is a great platform to motivate open-minded young students, especially from underrepresented groups, to pursue careers in science and engineering. The proposed work includes building a virtual deformation laboratory where students everywhere can learn about rock deformation. The experimental results will provide new insights into seismicity at subduction zones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sudden motions of faults cause earthquakes. Understanding the underlying mechanisms that are responsible for the transition between stable and unstable fault motions has long been a focus of experimental rock mechanics. In a classic framework based on the elastic rebound theory, an earthquake cycle includes the inter-seismic period of strain accumulation and the co-seismic period of sudden strain release along a tectonic fault. Fault motion is thought to be bimodal, i.e, a fault either creeps aseismically during the inter-seismic period, or a sudden rupture of the locked portion generates earthquakes. However, recent geophysical observations reveal frequent tectonic tremor activities and other low frequency, long duration events (referred to as slow slip events) during the inter-seismic period. Understanding of slow slip events can thus provide quantitative constraints on stress transfer and loading of the locked fault that can lead to earthquakes during an earthquake cycle.

 

In this study, we conducted experimental investigation to understand the stress and pore fluid pressure conditions that controls the slowness of fracture propagation and fault slip. Our experimental data elucidate how high pore pressure affects the slowness of fault propagation [Tamarkin et al., 2012; Ougier-Simonin and Zhu, 2013, 2015; French and Zhu, 2017]. We obtained correlations between the rate of stress drop and slip distance, which sheds light on the seismic moment release of these fluids triggered events [Ougier-Simonin and Zhu, 2015]. We also observed that fault slip enhanced by increasing pore pressure is sensitive to stress path and fluid pressurization rate [French et al., 2016]. Finally, we developed new experimental techniques and provided the first direct observation of fault growth and propagation in 3-dimensions at in-situ conditions [Renard et al., 2017]. The experimental results are made available through publications, web sites, and presentations.

 

This research project provided a good opportunity for training researchers of the future. Several postdoctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students have received support to participate in this project. A virtual deformation laboratory was built as a platform to foster collaboration, education and outreach beyond demographic and geographic borders.
